articles.title: Introduction to Political Methodology
articles.description: A PhD-level course on understanding data
articles.contents:
Contents
Getting Started
Data Analysis: R and RStudio
Version Control: git
Reference Management: Zotero
Social Annotation: Hypothesis
Memory Aid: Anki
Note-Taking Software (Optional)


Hello! Welcome to our class website.
Getting Started
There is a lot of software to install for this class, but in the instructions below I’ve tried to make it as straightforward as possible. (And everything is free!) Before the end of our first week, please complete the following steps.

Data Analysis: R and RStudio
For starters, you will need R. The most current version is available here. To download, click link for your operating system (i.e. Mac, Windows, Linux), then follow the instructions on the page.
R is the programming language itself, but it comes with a pretty unfriendly interface.

You don’t want to do all your typing in that lonely black box. Instead, you want RStudio, a piece of software that makes R much prettier. Download the RStudio Desktop version here.
Version Control: git
Professional coders use a version control system called git to keep track of their code. If you’re on a Mac, skip this section. Your machine already has it installed.1 If you use a PC, follow the installation instructions here.
Using git to track changes in your code involves a bit of struggle on the front end, but it is well worth it (Bryan 2017). I’ll walk you through the basics in class.
Reference Management: Zotero
This software makes it blindingly simple to keep track of and format your citations. It also plays really nicely with RStudio. Download it here and follow the setup instructions. The Chrome extension is particularly useful; anything you find on the Internet can be saved to your library with one click.
Social Annotation: Hypothesis
This semester, we’ll be using a social annotation platform called Hypothesis. That way, everyone will be able to post comments/questions/concerns/memes directly into the reading assignments. Follow these steps to get started:
Click the book icon in the top-right corner of the course website. This will take you to our Hypothesis Group Page.
If you don’t already have an account, you will be prompted to create one. Make your username something like firstname_lastname so we know who is posting!
Hypothesis works best with Google Chrome. If you don’t have it, install it here.
Install the Chrome extension. When you do, it should take you to a welcome page with instructions on how to log in, pin the extension, and start annotating pages!

Go to the syllabus and add your questions/comments/memes. Whenever you annotate a reading, just make sure that you are posting to the Group instead of Public (see the dropdown menu at the top of the extension).
Memory Aid: Anki
Take 20 minutes and play through Case (2018). If you’re convinced, download Anki. It’s not the prettiest spaced repetition software out there, but it is free, streamlined, highly customizable, and has a large, dedicated fanbase.
Note-Taking Software (Optional)
While we’re talking software, consider how you want to organize all the notes you generate in grad school. Information is going to be coming at you like a firehouse, and you’ll want a system that you can trust as your “external brain.”2 I highly recommend reading Ahrens (2017), a book that is much more fascinating than a book about note-taking should rightfully be.


Ahrens, Sönke. 2017. How to Take Smart Notes: One Simple Technique to Boost Writing, Learning and Thinkingfor Students, Academics and Nonfiction Book Writers.


Bryan, Jennifer. 2017. “Excuse Me, Do You Have a Moment to Talk about Version Control?” https://doi.org/10.7287/peerj.preprints.3159v2.


Case, Nicky. 2018. “How To Remember Anything Forever-Ish.” https://ncase.me/remember/.


I think? If you’re on a Mac and you can’t get git to work, let me know!↩︎
Don’t be like I was in grad school and write all your notes in a bunch of random notebooks that you throw in the trash at the end of the semester; so much wasted effort!

↩︎

Contents
Reading Assignments
Problem Set

This week, we will make sure that everything we need is installed and working on our computers. Make sure you’ve completed everything from the Getting Started section on the home page.
Reading Assignments
Before Week 2, please read and annotate the following:
Healy Preface (and complete the package installation instructions at the bottom)
Healy Chapter 2
Healy Chapter 3
Problem Set
Find the file R/week-01/problem-set-1.Rmd in our GitHub repository. Open it and make the following changes:
Edit the metadata so that you are the author.
Follow the instructions in the comments of each code chunk.
Knit to PDF.
Submit the knitted PDF document to eLC by our next class.
